pro_critic_reviews.summary: If you’re looking for a film that’s just about guaranteed to make you feel good, you’d be well advised to drop by Daddy’s Home.

In its best moments, it's a sly exposé of the frailties of the contemporary male self-image and in its lesser moments a simplistic slapstick. This being a Will Ferrell comedy, sometimes those moments are one and the same.
Anders had many opportunities to pit the dads against each other directly, but trades in the cheesy, expected route for devious mind games.

Consider it a predictable movie with flashes of unpredictability, one that actually coaxes some early laughs with, yes, scatological wit, then makes us groan when it shamefully takes the low road back to poopville a bit later on.
The world needs great Will Ferrell comedies. Unfortunately, this isn't one of them.
If it all ends in cornball reconciliation, the dumb, fuzzy smile it leaves suggests it’s well earned.

Lame Ferrell, through some weird freak of his talent, tends to be the best Ferrell, and despite the film’s general mediocrity in most departments – let us swish briskly over everything about the way it looks – his floundering star turn delivers the goods.
Overconfidence in the face of mediocrity is something Ferrell usually satirizes. This time, he’s more of a participant.
Daddy’s Home is not the world of Peak Ferrell, where jokes fly fast and absurdism rules the day. Instead, it is a land of predictable punchlines, easy sight gags and easier paycheques.
Daddy’s Home is a movie with a one-joke premise: Will Ferrell, he’s a pincushion of punishment. Make him screech. Watch him squirm.

The problem with Ferrell’s character is he goes from bland to desperate to off the rails — and very little about that transition is genuinely funny. The problem with Wahlberg’s character is he never seems all that dangerous or mysterious.
What keeps Daddy's Home watchable is Wahlberg's checkmate machismo, as the intimidating foil necessary for Ferrell's namby-pambyism to register.
There are a few laughs here and there. Most come at the expense of Ferrell, who plays the kind of hapless (and occasionally shirtless) straight arrow that the actor could turn out in his sleep.
Such a hit-and-miss mess that it makes the wild-and-crazy-to-the-point-of-sometimes-flailing tenor of “Anchorman”  and other such Ferrell vehicles feel like finely-tuned Logitech vehicles.
To be fair, Ferrell is almost always at least mildly funny, even when doing something as lame as skateboarding into a power line, but Wahlberg’s cowboy shtick just seems half-hearted.
The performers are all skilled enough to make something of this tired material.
Ferrell and Wahlberg are both game, but the material only sporadically lets them let loose and do something truly creative, while poor Cardellini transitions from naggy to unreliable.
Fitfully entertaining, and even more rarely actually funny, Daddy's Home, tellingly, only really comes alive in the very last portion of the third act.
Daddy’s Home is the white bread of family comedies, stuffed with everything you’ve seen before.

Ferrell and Wahlberg previously paired up in "The Other Guys", one of the great comedies of the millennium, but put aside any expectation that their latest collaboration might even come close to that sublime masterpiece.
Not that there’s anything wrong with raunch. But in the Judd Apatow era of raunch-coms, Anders’ version is pretty weak tea.
Daddy’s Home is one of those comedies that is not terribly good, but not nearly as terrible as it might have been.
Daddy’s Home raises the occasional smile, but it’s not exactly Wahlberg or Ferrell’s finest hour.
Directed by Sean Anders, the film goes out of its way to contrive its central masculinity crises in ways that quickly settle for lame, lowest common denominator jokes.
It’s by-numbers filmmaking that rarely adds up to anything worth the price of admission.
By playing it too safe, Daddy’s Home never finds that comic sweet spot and never rises above, “Well, it’s not awful.”

Its rhythms are sluggish, its jokes predictable and the gags are set up with such thudding deliberateness that even the sight of Ferrell losing control of a motorcycle, careening through the air and crashing straight through his house barely raises an eyebrow.
Daddy’s Home isn’t so much a lump of coal as an empty box.
Though Will Ferrell has made a career out of his own debasement, the film quickly becomes too cruel to generate laughter for anyone who would empathize with him.

Daddy’s Home is an ugly psychological cockfight posing as a family-friendly comedy. Laugh-free — except for some farcical, life-threatening stunts at the expense of Will Ferrell’s character, Brad — it is best avoided unless a movie that has the attitude and mind-set of a schoolyard bully happens to be your thing.

user_reviews.text: Was expecting a decent comedy going in and was rather surprised that it was a lot better than I expected it to be. Ferrell and Wahlberg work so well together and it shows on screen several times. Very funny through out and manages to avoid getting overly sappy with the emotional scenes in the film. Definitely worth watching.

It's not a bad film at all, in fact it was pretty enjoyable and entertaining. Some of the humor really worked and some didn't. The chemistry between Mark and Will was pretty hilarious and the premise was also cool. The trailer made it look like a good vs, bad dad comedy, but in reality, you get heartwarming soft little comedy that kids should enjoy. Great Christmas Movie to watch with your family and friends! (81/100)
it's a good movie...    anyone know why it got panned by critics
I didn't like the trailer, my expectations were ultra low when I watched the movie. After 10 mins of watching it, the movie was actually funny! and it started getting better and better till the end!
Returning in clever and fresh comedy, Wahlberg and Ferrell might just be the best surprise duo in comedy.

This is a family comedy worth watching. Although it seemed to open up to be another clichéd dumb comedy, it is considerably clever in it's conclusion and makes for one sweetly hilarious compromise for both dad and dad. Just be warned, slapstick humour is firm and prominent.

Nareszcie komedia, w której najlepsze gagi nie zostały zdradzone w trailerze! Will Ferrel i Mark Whalberg wykonali świetną robotę. Każdy żart jest napędzany ich stosunkiem do siebie. Oczywiście jest parę kompletnie  nie śmiesznych, ale ogólnie film jako komedia sprawdza się dobrze. W dodatku Daddy's home ma morał! I to całkiem niezły. Warto zobaczyć, nie pożałujecie.

I can't say this movie is for everyone but if you possess a silly lighthearted sense of humor I think you will find this to be quite entertaining. I watched it on my flight this week and liked it so much I watched it again on my return flight. Is it a little far-fetched & silly ...yes it is but come on people it's a comedy lighten up on the critical reviews.  It made me laugh out loud at many of the scenes so I say go for it
Fun and enjoyable but understand, this isn't high brow comedy, it's Will Ferrell.  Lot's of slapstick, some cliche jokes but it works and if you enjoy this type of humor, it's worth seeing.
This movie is recommended ... a must watch comedy.

This movie stars Mark Wahlberg and Will Ferrell. It is funny from beginning to end. Ferrell, of course is known for his sense of humor, but Wahlberg really steals the show. Wahlberg who usually plays these serious and tough characters is brilliant as the funnyman in this comedy. The two actors work well together and have great comedic chemistry. Could not stop laughing throughout the entire movie.
A great movie. You won't get the humor if you have never been a parent. One scene, the basketball game, was a trite waste of 10 minutes. Otherwise, fine.

Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg made a funny mismatched cop duo in “The Other Guys.” This time around, they’re hindered by a lousy script. Ferrell plays the step father who wants to be accepted by his wife’s 2 kids. Things are going well until their birth father (Wahlberg) shows up. The potential for comic competition is there, but the setups aren’t clever and the jokes fall flat. The only time this movie is worth watching is when Wahlberg has his shirt off. This film has some ghastly pandering product placement, esp. a car commercial.

The joke of the movie (good guy vs. bad guy) escalates in just about every way it can. Will’s character is looked down on by his kids, his boss, and his acquaintances. Mark’s character is the exact opposite. He has what appears to be an easy time in all he does.

This movie was great. It uses humor and comedy to depict, in a way, real life situations with people that go through this. Ferrell and Wahlburg make a great team in bringing laughs and heart warming moments. Of course the movie is not perfect but for about 95% of it I was laughing or smiling. Other than the basketball scene that is painfully awkward and weird to watch its a great movie.
Four genuine laughs, a dozen or so chuckles and many pained smiles.

"Daddy’s Home" stars Linda Gardelini, Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg in this comedy based on a story by Brian Burns and a screenplay co-written and co-directed by Sean Anders and John Morris. Seeking to recapture the terrific chemistry that Messrs. Ferrell and Wahlberg had in the film "The Other Guys", Mr. Ferrell plays a sweet and mild mannered husband and step-dad married to Mr. Wahlberg’s ex-wife. The film examines the inevitable conflict that exists between the divorced biological father who wants to retain some identity with his kids in spite of the step-dad now occupying the family residence. Obviously a subject more serious than comedic, the film tries to interject humor and to a certain extent succeeds. It is a light and easy film to watch with no great surprises enriched by the pleasant demeanor and screen presence of Mr. Ferrell.  I give the film a 6 with the warning that it needn’t be on your must see list of films for 2015.

The worst movie I've seen since walking out of The Sting II in 1983.  The only funny parts are painful sight gags by Will Ferrell.  There's no wit, no originality, nothing in the least thought provoking.

Mixed feelings about this. On the one hand, its a bunch of re-done cliches. Cool guy v. nerdy, family guy. I can do vs. you can't. The only difference is the circumstances these roles fit into. And, obviously makes/breaks the movie. Neither Ferrell or Wahlberg can really act- so in that regard its too over the top sarcastic. Maybe as a parent I could "get" this more, but I'm not....and I don't
Step-dad versus stepped-in dad.

Due to the last collaboration with Ferrel and Wahlberg i was actually quite liked the other guys, but Daddy's Home is a pretty awfully written mess. The jokes don't really come in until the second half of the film as the film spends too much time on the premise of the film but hardly any time on the jokes of the film. The jokes on that matter are also pretty lame, with only a few making me mildly laugh. The direction of the film is also off and no real chemistry is felt within the casts, with the film just fluctuating it's character plot lines in different directions all over the place and just making the viewing nauseating. On the plus side Thomas Haden Church (Leo Holt) and Hannibal Buress (Griff) were actually the funniest parts of the film, playing their parts pretty well despite being minor characters. Overall this film is a major let down and not really worth the watch, which i am quite sad to say. A film to see if there's nothing else on or if it perhaps pops up on tv.

Not all that funny a few laughs but co-writer director Sean Anders (Horrible Bosses 2) manages to put charm and wackiness into this comedy and makes the collaboration with Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg priceless, where the chemistry with each other is nice. The problem I had with this film is it's a mediocre comedy with bland performances, but it's a good comedy. Will Ferrell plays Brad Taggart a radio executive, who has a big heart and wants to be the best step-father ever to his wife's (Linda Cardellini) two children (Scarlett  Estevez and Owen Vaccaro). When her bad boy ex-husband Dusty (Mark Wahlberg) comes back to town, Brad feels insecure about him being there, Dusty wants to get back together with Sarah, so him and Brad have a competition on who wins the family. Dusty demonstrates his flair for athletics, home repair and bad boy charisma. So Brad finds himself in a tough situation to battle one-up his rival and win his family. Despite wasting talented comedy stars Will Ferrell and Mark Whalberg, they make bland performances, but they make this movie rock, still an enjoyable film despite it's a mediocre PG-13 comedy. 3 out 5 stars

I was a little worried that watching Daddy's Home in the theatre would be a waste of time. I had heard that this film has aimed for more of a family audience, but I really didn't get that vibe. This is not a kids movie at all. Anyone who has seen The Other Guys knows that Mark Wahlberg and Ferrell have chemistry and it is one of the most important parts of this film and that was what kept it on an enjoyable level because I was not laughing out loud at all the jokes. The cast is pretty solid. I really liked the addition of Hannibal Burress, he was one of the funniest characters in the film although he really didn't need to be there. There is so much product placement in Daddy's Home that it almost feels like they are parodying it. There is a pretty good amount of heart in this movie and although the story is not exactly the most believable its still a warming end.

This movie feel like they are trying to recreate the chemistry between Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg in "The Other Guys" But falls extremely flat. Most the film feels so forced and some scenes just feel awkward. The film has it moments but they are few and far between and trailers will ruin most of it for your. I feel like much more could have come from this movie but didn't. Overall don't bother with this film unless you like simple humor or really really like Will Ferrell/Mark Wahlberg.

Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg have good comedic chemistry, if you need real proof look no further than The Other Guys, this isn’t quite as funny. If you’re hoping for something like The Other Guys, these two films share a few similarities but are ultimately very different films. Daddy’s Home has its stretches of good humor, but ultimately drags on, and offers nothing really new to the comedy genre. It should be clarified that the film has a good amount of humor, so if that’s the main concern Daddy’s Home should deliver.

It's decent enough but easily forgettable. Ferrell and Wahlberg have great chemistry and there are consistent laughs but at the end, it's just another typical Ferrell movie...i like him but he needs to go back to his routes  instead of doing these indifferent and weary movies.

Another testosterone battle? Wow, I'm so glad I wasted an hour and a half of my life on this movie! Reminds me, not in plot, but in the humor level of Vacation – also released this year. Strangely enough, I always get corraled into seeing these horrible movies knowing full well in advance that they are truly a waste of time.
Daddy's Home doesn't even have a plot. Basically, it is nothing but two actors making fools of themselves. The film delivers little laughs, and to sum the film up, it's a bore.

When you think "Daddy's Home!", you think of seeing your daddy coming home for the day! When you think Daddy's Home, it doesn't really pull out anything new. It's just an average battle against Dad and Step-Dad. This isn't a bad film, but it's not a good one either. It just needs to be a bit better.

This was boring at best. I cracked a smile perhaps 5 times, didn't laugh at all. I felt like I was at a middle school lunch table for an hour and a half, and checking my watch wondering how much longer I'd have to sit through it. This is a great movie to put on in the background, but definitely not worth the time to watch it intently.

Daddy's home is a mix of humour and boredom. There are scenes which are uplifting and quite hilarious. Then there are scenes which drag on for no reason. I would suggest it's a film you watch with your friends rather than parents.

Can I get my money back?.  Went with a birthday party group but is definitley NOT appropriate for kids under 15 ( was classified as PG in Australia which means ok for kids under 15).  Most jokes had a sexual meaning, even a scene where it looked like the guy was masturbating...... wish I could erase this from the memory of my kids 11 and 14.  And me too.

This movie was better than I thought it was going to be and there were many funny moments in this movie. The concept was awesome. A loving father is being constantly overshadowed by the bigger much more buff stepdad. As the two fathers try to win over there kids affection antics ensure. Overall this is a pretty decent comedy some of the jokes are very funny and some are not. Mark walberg and will Ferrell show that they are a comedic duo. This is a good movie with a couple of unnecessary scenes that were trying to be funny but ultimately fell flat. So take the family to see this. You will ultimately have a good time but it's not perfect

This has to be one of the worst comedies out in cinemas currently, the previews of the film that are in the trailers are the only slightly funny parts throughout the film. The best part was seeing Mark Wahlberg being punched in the face (I assumed it was for how bad the film is). But If you like having meanings of being a Father rammed down your throat then by all means you'll love it, but if you are looking for relatable jokes, slapstick comedy and cringe worthy moments... Then expect to be monumentally disappointed by the lack of all those comedic elements that make a good comedy. I do think the age rating should be 15 due to quite a lot of bad language, but this is not effecting my thoughts on the film it's just if you are looking for a film that is family friendly. I would not recommend unless you are a die hard Ferrell or Wahlberg fan.

I did NOT like this movie, it used too many bad language and I found that all of the funny scenes were in the trailer. I should have known it was going to be like all the Will Ferrell movies these days.

Wahlberg and Ferrell are reunited after "The Other Guys" in another enjoyable comedy. It might not hit the high hilarity moments of their previous collaboration, but there is still plenty of amusement to be found here. Not to mention quite a bit of heart.
While not nearly as good as The Other Guys, this film is passable with enough laugh out loud moments to keep you satisfied.  I wouldn't mind seeing more films with Ferrell and Wahlberg.  B-

Good comedy and wasn't to vulgar for younger kids. There are a few parts you might have to cover a young ones ears but not bad. I enjoyed it a lot more than I was expecting to. Hilarious and good entertainment.

Wahlberg and Ferrell exude oodles of chemistry as two men in competition with one another in this lighthearted romp about fatherhood, which is little more than an extended set of good cop, bad cop. There's more than a smile and a chuckle here.

A new low for Will Ferrell, and that's saying a lot. Whatever funny parts of this movie exist, you've already seen them in the trailer. No humor, no wit, complete lack of a plot. Don't waste your time.

Decent comedy and if you are a fan of Ferell's comedy movies you will really enjoy this one too. As I am not too crazy about him I liked it but wasn't that huge of a fan of it. Still worth a watch though.
"Ferrell: Good Daddy -  Wahlberg: Bad Daddy" Who won the battle of this indecisive comedy?

Will Farrell's innocent persona went over well in "Elf" but it's gotten old.  Will portrays it again in this movie and makes it a "here we go again" movie.  The story is interesting and could have been taken to a higher level.
Daddy's home is pretty good, but isn't for everyone. Mark and Will did great, for me it was very funny. The constant tension between the two only made it better with constant one ups man ship.

Movie does what it has to do. It makes you smile on the moments, and at the end, makes you feel good. Not my favorite actors, but they have done very good job. It's actually the same movie as all from Mark and acting mistake Will Ferrell. Screenplay is very predicted, but it's very normal for this kine of movie. Soo 5.

Ferrell & Wahlberg show good funny chemistry, but Daddy's home suffers from lack of creativity and funny ideas and afraid to explore its possibilities. The film piece on the verbal jokes and uses the body to make you laugh.
Hilarious movie! Will Ferrell never seems to leave me without a laugh. Mark Whalberg was great as well and I loved the cameos from Kobe Bryant and John Cena!

My husband and I laughed so hard until tears were coming out of our eyes and cramps in our sides.The movie hilariously and tastefully hit on key issues that Americans face. The father vs stepdad syndrome and how the kids play them both.The movie is for anyone who has experienced or witnessed male pride/dominance to the extreme.A job well done! Thanks for the Laughs guys keep em coming!
